entries.meaning: (India, historical) The building in which unmarried British army officers were quartered during the British Raj.
examples: Close by, but only to be glimpsed through the gateway in a high stucco wall, similarly shaded, is the bungalow once known as the chummery where three of four of Mr White's unmarried sub-divisional officers - usually Indians of the uncovenanted provincial civil service - used to live when not on tour in their own allotted areas of the district.

entries.meaning: (South Asia) The shared home of a group of men who are unmarried or working at a distance from their families.
examples: Dicky could not afford living in the chummery, modest as it was. He had to explain this before he moved to a single room next the office where he worked all day.
